title: Open Label Positron Emission Tomography (PET) Study With [11C]AZD2995 and [11C]AZD2184, Candidate PET Ligands for β Amyloid, to Determine and Compare in Vivo Brain Uptake and Distribution in Healthy Volunteers and Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The study is carried out in order to investigate if \[11C\]AZD2995, compared to \[11C\]AZD2184, is a more suitable PET ligand for in vivo imaging of β amyloid depositions in the human brain. In the study the two PET ligands will be examined in both healthy volunteers and patients with Alzheimer's Disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The protocol explicitly compares two carbon-11–labelled PET ligands for in vivo imaging of β‑amyloid deposition (i.e., a diagnostic imaging study), not a therapeutic intervention. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Act: Extracted interventions — [11C]AZD2995 and [11C]AZD2184 — which are radioligands developed for amyloid‑β PET imaging (AstraZeneca/academic publications). Both ligands bind Aβ and were evaluated in human PET studies to assess brain uptake and distribution. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: This is a diagnostic PET ligand comparison (biomarker/imaging) and does not test a disease‑modifying biologic or small molecule therapy, a cognitive enhancer, or a neuropsychiatric treatment — therefore it does not fit the four therapeutic categories and is classified as 'N/A'. The trial registry and published PET study confirm the imaging/diagnostic purpose. citeturn0search3turn0search1
